feedback.Physical object: Excluded — Pronoun usage is a linguistic practice, not a tangible entity.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Excluded — It is a cultural-linguistic convention, not a fabricated object.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Excluded — While referring to biological identity, the usage itself is not biological.
feedback.Fixed/static: Excluded — Pronoun conventions evolve across time and cultures.
feedback.Structural: Excluded — It does not serve a structural role in the physical or architectural sense.
feedback.Perceptible: Excluded — Pronouns are perceptible in speech or text, but the usage convention is abstract.
feedback.Material form: Excluded — Pronoun usage is not inherently material.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — It plays an active role in social signaling and communication.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Included — Pronouns are intentionally selected in communication to reflect identity or context.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Excluded — While communicative, the usage does not produce output in the mechanistic sense.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Excluded — It does not compute or regulate signals.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Excluded — It can affect perceptions but not internal states directly.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Excluded — Pronouns are part of language, not interactive agents.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Included — Usage is embedded within grammatical, cultural, and institutional systems.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Excluded — Pronoun meaning and usage rely on social interpretation.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — Language functions without any one pronoun.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Included — Pronouns stand in symbolically for individuals.
feedback.Communicative: Included — They are a fundamental tool for interpersonal reference.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Excluded — Though grammar-based, their core identity is symbolic and social.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Excluded — Pronouns do not form modular or hierarchical systems.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Included — Their correct or incorrect use signals social alignment or offense.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Excluded — Usage does not inherently refer to itself.
feedback.Temporal: Excluded — Usage adapts over time but does not intrinsically reference time.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Included — Pronoun meaning shifts based on speaker, subject, and sociocultural frame.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Included — Pronoun norms are built and enforced by social communities.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Included — Grammar systems, institutions, and communities define proper use.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Included — Pronouns are directly tied to personal and gender identity.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Included — Institutions and style guides enforce pronoun usage rules.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Included — Taught through language education and socialization.
feedback.Visible: Included — Appears in written and spoken communication.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Included — Usage depends heavily on situation, culture, and audience.
feedback.Widely known: Included — Pronoun conventions are broadly understood and debated.

encoding_notes: This encoding treats gender pronoun usage as a symbolic, communicative, identity-signaling system deeply embedded in sociolinguistic conventions. It avoids conflating material traits with linguistic functions. The corrected code '0084C9FF' reflects its purposive, referential, and socially governed nature.
